title: How to Facilitate a Group

steps.headline: Announce your group.
Research possible topics ahead of time.
steps.description: Look online and in books for ideas on what topics to choose. If you are leading a work group, get all the research and reports sent out a few days ahead of time so that everyone can be on the same page for the meeting.

steps.headline: Learn time management skills before you facilitate a group.
Mentally prepare yourself for facilitation.
steps.description: It can be exhausting to lead a group, especially for professional and emotional topics. Get a good night sleep and do some deep breathing techniques before you start the group meeting.

steps.headline: Set up an environment that facilitates discussion.
steps.description: Sitting in a circle is a classic approach, because no one is left out. Move chairs into a circle before anyone else arrives. Avoid a “classroom” approach. If everyone must see you, but can’t see each other, you will be more of an authority figure and have a harder time encouraging discussion between group members.

steps.headline: Practice neutrality.
steps.description: It is your job to encourage participation without affecting the outcome. If you are an opinionated person, practice holding your tongue in political or opinionated discussions.

steps.headline: Introduce yourself.
steps.description: Keep it brief, but announce your qualifications or interest in the success of the group. Aim to keep the introduction between one and two minutes long.

steps.headline: State the group rules if they are necessary for the function of the group.
steps.description: Groups like Alcoholics Anonymous have steps and traditions that are to be read at the beginning of each meeting. Don’t go overboard with rules, as they might restrict expression in the group.

steps.headline: Announce the purpose of the meeting.
steps.description: If there are desired outcomes or agenda points, review them now. Set times if necessary.

steps.headline: Adjust the structure of group discussion based on how many members you have.
steps.description: If you are leading a small group, you may be able to go around in a circle (Round Robin) so that everyone has a chance to speak. If you are leading a large group, you may need to encourage the raising of hands or free speaking. Announce the structure of the group before you start, so that everyone has the same expectations.

steps.headline: Don’t fall into “teaching behaviors.” This is when you begin to answer questions, state facts or speak frequently.
steps.description: You are serving as a neutral party, not a teacher.

steps.headline: Ask open-ended questions.
steps.description: Avoid asking questions to the group with yes or no answers. If they must be yes/no answers, ask group members to elaborate on why that is the answer.

steps.headline: Continue with follow-up questions if discussion doesn’t start immediately.
steps.description: Good follow-up questions include “How does that change the way you feel about X,Y,Z?” and “How do you think that applies to other issues that we are discussing?”

steps.headline: Break the group into smaller groups for projects or intimate discussion.
steps.description: If you are afraid that the group is too large to encourage adequate participation, small group work is a good way to encourage everyone in a group to interact.

steps.headline: Give positive reinforcement.
steps.description: Encourage positive interactions. Thank people for their contributions. Don’t be critical. Even if your group is created for critiques, criticism should be only give in small doses. Start each comment with positive reinforcement.

steps.headline: Suggest an energizer activity if you have a long meeting.
steps.description: Between subjects, encourage people to play a game, watch a related YouTube clip or get up and move around.

steps.headline: Deal with disagreements by finding common ground.
steps.description:
It is your job as the group leader to recognize potential arguments and try to move on in a productive way. Say, “It sounds like we have a difference of opinion.”
“Different points of view are encouraged in our group.”
“It sounds like you both feel passionate about this.”
“It seems that we can agree on X,Y,Z.”

steps.headline: Encourage other people to lead future discussions.
steps.description: This is a good way for people to feel joint ownership of a group and its goals.

steps.headline: Create an evaluation process.
steps.description: Ask people to take a questionnaire or discuss changes or issues wit you.
